t: “On*pn my bed night after night I sought him Whom*ln my soul loves; I*ln sought him but did not find him.
‘I*ln must arise now and go about the city; In*ln the streets and in the squares I*ln must seek him whom my soul loves.’ I*ln sought him but did not find him.
The*ln watchmen who make the rounds in the city found me, And*iln I*i said,*i ‘Have you seen him whom my soul loves?’

Scarcely*ln had I left them When*ln I found him whom my soul loves; I*ln held on to him and would not let him go Until*ln I had brought him to my mother’s house, And*ln into the room of her who conceived me.”
“I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By*ln the gazelles or by the hinds of the field, That*ln you will not arouse or awaken my*i love Until*ln she pleases.”
“What*pn is this coming up from the wilderness Like*ln columns of smoke, Perfumed*ln with myrrh and frankincense, With*ln all scented powders of the merchant?
Behold,*ln it is the traveling*i couch of Solomon; Sixty*ln mighty men around it, Of*ln the mighty men of Israel.
All*ln of them are wielders of the sword, Expert*ln in war; Each*ln man has his sword at his side, Guarding*iln against the terrors of the night.
King*ln Solomon has made for himself a sedan chair From*ln the timber of Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, Its*ln back of gold And*iln its seat of purple fabric, With*iln its interior lovingly fitted out By*ln the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ln forth, O daughters of Zion, And*ln gaze on King Solomon with the crown With*ln which his mother has crowned him On*ln the day of his wedding, And*ln on the day of his gladness of heart.”
